When a small group of living beings (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it originated (for example, if it moves above a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment from the one in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all, they still need the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to look less and less like the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they will no longer be considered members of the same species.
We call this process "speciation," which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which the destiny of humanity is dictated by an underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: the development of technology itself proceeds beyond the influence of cultural and political factors, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, one could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new methods of production are developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
The massive ownership of cars also leads to a greater incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat the physical injuries.

The use of ships to transport goods is by far the most efficient way to move large quantities of people and goods across the oceans.
Traditionally, the work of navies has been to ensure that your country maintains the ability to move your people and your goods, while interfering with your enemy's ability to do the same.

One of the most remarkable examples of this situation was the North Atlantic Campaign during World War II. The Americans were trying to get troops and equipment across the Atlantic Ocean to help Britain.
At the same time, the German Navy, using mainly U-Boats, was trying to stop this traffic.
If the Allies had failed, Germany would probably have been able to conquer Great Britain as it did the rest of Europe.

Ancient cultures and tribes began to keep them close by for easy access to milk, hair, meat and hides.

Domestic goats were usually kept in herds that roamed the hills or other grazing areas, often cared for by shepherds who were usually children or adolescents, similar to the more common term of shepherds. These pastoral methods are still in use today.
The “wagonways” were built in England in the 16th century.
Although wagon ways were simply made of parallel wooden planks, they allowed horses to pull heavier loads at higher speeds than on the slightly more accident-prone roads of the day.
Crossbars were introduced early on to keep the paths in place. However, it was soon realized that the paths would be more effective if they were equipped with a steel band on top.
This has become a common practice, but the iron wheels caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.
The first means of locomotion was walking: humans began walking upright two million years ago with the arrival of Homo Erectus ("upright man").
Their predecessors, the australopiths, did not walk upright as usual.
Bipedal specializations are found in the fossils of Australopithecus dating from 4.2 to 3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus may have walked on two legs as early as seven million years ago.

After its adoption by Congress on July 4, a handwritten document signed by President of Congress John Hancock and Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few streets away, to the printing shop of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, now known as the ‘Dunlap Broadsides’.
The first public reading of the document was made by John Nixon in Independence Hall on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on July 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy arrived in London on August 10.
The 25 Dunlap copies that we know of are the oldest surviving copies of the document. The original manuscript has not survived.

Biological clocks are self-sufficient oscillators that will continue a cycle of functioning for a certain period of time, even in the absence of external stimulation.

Hershey and Chase used phages, or viruses, to implant their own DNA into a bacterium.

Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and vehicles between two points, and the interactions they have with each other.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study traffic flow because the behaviour of drivers cannot be predicted with 100 per cent certainty.
Fortunately, drivers tend to act in a reasonably coherent range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonable coherence and can be represented mathematically in an approximate way.
To better represent the traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) the bandwidth, (2) the density and (3) the speed.
These relationships help with planning, design and operation of roadway facilities.
Insects were the first animals to fly. Their ability to fly allowed them to escape their enemies more easily and find food and mates more efficiently.
Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings along their body.
This gives them more places to hide from predators.
Today, the only insects that cannot fold their wings are dragonflies and mayflies.

The Amazon River is the second-longest and largest river on Earth. It carries eight times the volume of water of the second-largest river.
The Amazon is also the largest river in the world, sometimes reaching 10 km in width.
Not less than 20% of the water that flows from the rivers of the planet into the oceans comes from the Amazon.

At the other end of the spectrum, one transforms into an unrecognizable individual who feels that he/she must change everything that the group has created up to now and do things his/her way.

Virtual teams are subject to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Members of a virtual team often function as a point of contact for their immediate physical group.
They have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams can meet according to different time zones, which may not be understood by their local management.
The presence of a real ‘invisible team’ (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique feature of a virtual team.
The ‘invisible team’ is the management team to which each member reports. It sets the standards for each of them.

Field trips are an integral part of any school class. Often, a teacher would like to take his or her students to places where a bus trip is not possible.

The solution is provided by technology in the form of virtual field trips. Students can view ancient artifacts in a museum, visit an aquarium, or admire a beautiful work of art while sitting with their class.
Participating in an excursion is also a great way to reflect on a trip and share your experiences with future generations.

For example, students from Bennet High School in North Carolina design a website each year about their visit to the state capital. Each year, the site is updated, but the old versions are kept online to serve as an album.

Blogs can also help students to improve their writing skills. Even though students often try blogging with poor grammar and spelling, the fact that they have an audience usually improves the situation.
As students are often the most critical audience, the author of the blog begins to try to improve his writing to avoid criticism.
In addition, blogging « forces students to better know the world around them ». The need to generate interest from the public encourages students to be intelligent and interesting (Toto, 2004).
Blogs are a tool that stimulates collaboration and encourages students to extend their learning beyond the traditional school day.

"When used properly, blogs can help students to strengthen their analytical and critical thinking skills: by responding actively to online content, they can confront their opinions with those of others and expose their own views on well-defined topics (Oravec, 2002)."

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BCE, and was used by the Phoenicians, the Romans, and the Merinides as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who had destroyed it and then rebuilt it and baptized it Casa Branca, finally abandoned it in 1755 after an earthquake.
The Moroccan sultan rebuilt the city under the name Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in all of Morocco for shopping.

Around the old medina, it is easy to find places where you can buy traditional Moroccan products such as tagines, pottery, leather goods, hookahs, and all sorts of trinkets, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town located in the extreme east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the volcano Nyiragongo which buried most of the streets of the city, particularly the city centre.
Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside of Goma should be researched to understand the state of the fighting that continues in the North Kivu province.
The town is also the starting point for the ascent of the Nyiragongo volcano and for treks among the cheapest gorilla trekking in Africa.
You can use boda-bodas (motorcycle taxis) to get around Goma. The normal (local) fare is about 500 Congolese francs for a short ride.
Combined with its relative inaccessibility, 'Timbuktu' has become a metaphor for distant and exotic countries.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in northeastern South Africa and borders the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwe border to the north and the Crocodile River to the south.
The total area of the park is 19,500 km2, which is divided into 14 ecozones, each of which has its own unique fauna.
It is one of the best-known theme parks in South Africa and is considered the jewel of South African National Parks (SANParks).
As with all South African national parks, there are daily entrance and conservation fees for the park.
It can be advantageous to obtain a Wild Card that gives access to some South African parks, as well as to all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island gives its name to the territory of Hong Kong and represents the main attraction for many tourists.

The majority of urban development on Hong Kong Island is concentrated on the northern shore.

The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove forest in the world, stretching 80 km (50 miles) from the coast to the hinterland of Bangladesh and India.
The Sundarbans have been designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest located on Indian territory is called the Sundarbans National Park.
The forests, however, are not composed only of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last remnants of the majestic jungles that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which about a third is covered by water/marshland.
Sundarbans is a nature reserve since 1966, you can find there about 400 Bengal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer.

The Oyapock Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River to link the towns of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers rise to a height of 83 m; it is 378 m long and has two lanes 3.5 m wide.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The structure was completed in August 2011, but it was not opened to traffic until March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts are expected to be completed.
The Guaraní were the largest indigenous group living in what is now the eastern part of Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters and practicing subsistence agriculture.
Other indigenous tribes inhabiting the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived mainly by fishing, hunting, or gathering.
In the 16th century, Paraguay, formerly known as "the giant province of the Indies", was born from the meeting between the Spanish conquerors and the indigenous populations.
The Spaniards inaugurated the period of colonization, which lasted three centuries.
Since the founding of Asuncion in 1537, Paraguay has managed to retain a large part of its indigenous character and identity.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands pound (FKP) whose value is equivalent to one British pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank in the islands, located in Stanley, opposite the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is a commonly accepted currency throughout the islands, while in Stanley, credit cards and US dollars are also often accepted.
On nearby islands, credit cards are unlikely to be accepted, even if it is possible that British and American currencies will be accepted. Speak to the owners in advance to agree on a payment method.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falkland Islands outside of the islands, so change it before leaving the islands.
Montevideo being located south of the Equator, winter in the northern hemisphere corresponds to summer there and vice versa.

Winter can be deceptively cold: temperatures rarely drop below zero, but the wind and humidity combine to give the impression that it is colder than the thermometer says.

The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang on either side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a security problem: in fact, the user’s feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has a foot caught in the stirrup, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a smooth, narrow sole.
Then, some saddles, notably English ones, have safety bars that allow a stirrup to fall off the saddle if it is pulled backwards by a rider who falls.

Violent weather is the generic term for any dangerous meteorological phenomenon capable of causing damage, serious social disruption or loss of human life.

Violent winds, hail, excessive rainfall, and fires are forms and effects of violent weather, just as thunderstorms, tornadoes, hurricanes, and typhoons.

Japanese work culture is more hierarchical and formal than that to which Westerners are accustomed.
